purpose_overview.goal: Build lean muscle mass while controlling fat gain, using a structured eating window.
purpose_overview.approach: Consume a caloric surplus during an 8-hour feeding window, aligned with training sessions for optimal performance and recovery.
purpose_overview.best_for: Intermediate–advanced lifters, athletes who prefer time-restricted eating, and those who struggle with appetite control or want simplicity.
purpose_overview.why_it_works: Supports muscle growth via adequate calorie/protein intake, while fasting may improve insulin sensitivity and appetite regulation (Tinsley & La Bounty, JISSN, 2015).

caloric_strategy.maintenance_calculation: Estimate TDEE with Mifflin-St Jeor or Cunningham equation.
caloric_strategy.surplus: Add 10–15% (≈ 200–400 kcal/day for most) due to reduced feeding window efficiency.
caloric_strategy.target_weight_gain: 0.25–0.5% body weight per week (e.g., 0.2–0.5 kg for 80 kg person).
caloric_strategy.adjustment_tip: Since fasting limits eating time, calorie-dense whole foods may be necessary (e.g., nuts, olive oil, rice, dried fruit).

rationale.protein: Maximizes muscle protein synthesis (Morton et al., 2018). Essential in fewer meals due to IF.
rationale.carbohydrates: Fuels resistance training and glycogen replenishment.
rationale.fats: Supports hormones & absorption of fat-soluble vitamins.
rationale.fiber: Aids satiety, digestion, and gut health.

meal_timing_distribution.protein_distribution: 0.4–0.55 g/kg per meal × 3–4 meals (Schoenfeld & Aragon, JISSN, 2018).

training_integration.pre_workout: Balanced meal 1–3 hr before (protein + complex carbs + vegetables).
training_integration.fasted_training: Take EAAs/BCAAs (~10 g) or whey hydrolysate pre/intra to reduce muscle breakdown.
training_integration.post_workout: 20–40 g protein + 1–1.5 g/kg carbs within 2 hr.

meal_timing_distribution.hydration: 35–45 ml/kg/day water. Black coffee, tea, and zero-calorie drinks are fasting-friendly. Electrolytes recommended in long fasted states with heavy sweating.

supplements_optional: Creatine Monohydrate (3–5 g/day) – Strong evidence for strength & lean mass.
Whey/Plant Protein Powder – Helps reach protein goals within short window.
Vitamin D & Omega-3 – Useful if diet lacks exposure or fish intake.
Electrolytes – Beneficial in fasted training + hot climates.
Caffeine (3–6 mg/kg pre-workout) – Supports performance during fasting.

monitoring_adjustments.body_weight: Weekly average – Adjust calories if <0.25% or >0.5% gain/week.
monitoring_adjustments.strength_progress: Weekly – If stagnating, increase calories or adjust workout timing.
monitoring_adjustments.body_composition: Every 4–6 weeks – Track via photos, BIA, or skinfolds.

advantages: May improve insulin sensitivity & nutrient partitioning.
Supports lean bulk by limiting snacking & overeating.
Can be sustainable for those who prefer large, satisfying meals.
limitations: Hitting calorie targets can be difficult in 8-hour window (especially for hard gainers).
Less flexibility for social meals outside window.
Training fasted may impair performance for some individuals.
Requires attention to protein distribution for optimal muscle growth.
scientific_references: Morton RW et al. (2018). Protein supplementation on resistance training-induced gains in muscle mass and strength. Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376–384.
Tinsley GM & La Bounty PM (2015). Effects of intermittent fasting on body composition and clinical health markers. J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 12:47.
Schoenfeld BJ & Aragon AA (2018). How much protein can the body use in a single meal for muscle-building? J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 15:10.
Kerksick CM et al. (2017). ISSN position stand: nutrient timing. J Int Soc Sports Nutr, 14:33.
American College of Sports Medicine (2022). Nutrition and Athletic Performance Position Stand.
